descriptionSet.description: A little girl with blonde hair is standing next to a tub full of water, playing with a piece of soap. A doll and some other toys as well as a children's book are lying on the floor around the tub. In the background carved wooden walls and a folding screen decorated with plants can be seen.

inscription.text: GOODWIN'S IVY SOAP [inscription on wooden frame]

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: "Ivy" Soap It Floats
text-en: "Ivy" Soap for washing Everybody & Everything.
text-en: GOODWIN'S IVY SOAP [inscription on wooden frame]

description-en: A little girl with blonde hair is standing next to a tub full of water, playing with a piece of soap. A doll and some other toys as well as a children's book are lying on the floor around the tub. In the background carved wooden walls and a folding screen decorated with plants can be seen. (gs/tb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Ivy (Ivory) soap advertisement normally featured little white children playing with soap. An accident in the late nineteenth century by a plant worker in Cincinnati who left a batch of mixture in a stirring machine for longer than needed is said to have created this soap (with a hollowed inside) “that floats!” However, long before it was named Ivory after a biblical reference, the soap was somewhat unimaginatively called “white soap.” (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The text proclaims “Ivy Soap for washing Everybody and Everything.” Implicit in the words and the image of the little white child bathing her dolls is an assumption of white superiority. Indeed many soap companies including Pears, Monkey Brand Soap, Lux and Ivy would actually use images of marginalized groups of people (working class, native or people of color, for instance) purified by soap suggesting, as McClintock notes, that it could “regenerate the Family of Man by washing from the skin the very stigma of racial and class degeneration.” (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Children were also useful for advertising because of the association suggested by their skin ("like babies"). This association could later be transposed onto the figure of a grown women as was the case with Pears that marketed a gentle transparent soap made of glycerin. The company ran beauty contests for little children and many "Miss Pears" would later become actresses or models. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Blonde hair is a distinctive visual marker on advertising images for being Western and therefore an exclusive marker for whiteness. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: According to Anne McClintock soaps like Pears played a decisive role in colonialism as its advertising carried a powerful racial ideology she refers to as "commodity racism". Many soap advertising images in the colonial period conveyed the message that soap is the means to bring civilization. For instance, one ad from 1899 argued that "The first step toward lightening THE WHITE MAN'S BURDEN is through teaching the virtues of cleanliness. PEARS' SOAP is a potent fact in brightening the dark corners of the earth as civilization advances." Citation taken from: http://science.jrank.org/pages/8820/Consumerism-SOAP.html#ixzz1Vf1A9MCv. Thus, soap was one of the major symbolic carriers of whiteness and imperialism and Victorian notions of gender. (la)
related literature: Dyer, Richard and Christine Gledhill 2009. "Wanted: Cultured ladies Only! Female Stardom and Cinema in India 1930s-1950s". Urbana and Chicago: University of Illinois Press. (gs)
related literature: Gadihoke, Sabika 2010. "Selling Soap and Stardom: The Story of Lux", Tasveer Ghar essay.
